member.name: T:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DefaultLinkTypes
member.summary: Type of link moves

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DefaultLinkTypes.Incremental
member.summary: The tool descends at rapid feed from the safe area to the specified incremental distance above the target point, and then plunges the remaining distance. If you have a multi-axis toolpath, the tool retracts a set distance along the tool axis and then retracts to the safe area. It comes down from the safe area and completes the approach along the tool axis

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DefaultLinkTypes.Safe
member.summary: The tool moves to the safe area before making the link move.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DefaultLinkTypes.Skim
member.summary: The links traverse clear of the part by the specified incremental distance, descend at rapid feed to the specified incremental distance above the contact point, and then plunge the remaining distance.

member.name: T:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveDirection
member.summary: The orientation of the links.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveDirection.ToolAxis
member.summary: The retract and approach moves have the same orientation as the tool axis.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveDirection.Normal
member.summary: The retract and approach moves are normal to the contact point (or normal to the Leads In/Out). This can be particularly useful for tipped disc cutters where moving along the tool axis may not be possible (for example, when undercutting).

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveDirection.Tangent
member.summary: The retract and approach moves are tangential to the toolpath.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveDirection.Radial
member.summary: The retract and approach moves are perpendicular to both the tool axis and the tangent direction of the toolpath.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.LeadIn
member.summary: Lead in first choice, Settings to control the tool's movement as it approaches the stock, before beginning a cutting move.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.LeadInSecond
member.summary: Lead in second choice, Settings to control the tool's movement as it approaches the stock, before beginning a cutting move.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.LeadOut
member.summary: Lead out first choice, Settings to control the tool's movement after it leaves the stock, at the end of a cutting move.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.LeadOutSecond
member.summary: Lead out second choice, Settings to control the tool's movement after it leaves the stock, at the end of a cutting move.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.FirstLeadIn
member.summary: Settings to specify a First Lead In move that is different from the subsequent lead in moves.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.LastLeadOut
member.summary: Settings to specify a Last Lead Out move that is different from the previous lead out moves.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.LeadInExtension
member.summary: These options add an additional Lead In before the existing one.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.LeadOutExtension
member.summary: These options add an additional Lead Out after the existing one.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.OverlapDistance
member.summary: Enter the distance by which a Lead in or Lead out can overlap a closed toolpath segment.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.AllowStartPointToBeMoved
member.summary: When selected, this option moves the start points on closed toolpath segments to try and find a non-gouging position. When deselected, PowerMILL will not move the start points - this means that if you carefully position a start point, you can prevent PowerMILL from moving it.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.AddLeadsToShortLinks
member.summary:
When selected, this option adds leads to short links. By default, leads are applied to all link moves. However, for reasons of efficiency and/or quality, there can be occasions where you want leads on long link moves and on the moves at the start and end of the toolpath, but don't want leads on short link moves.
This feature available on PowerMILL 2016 and lower versions, otherwise exception will be thrown

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.AddLeadsAtToolAxisDiscontinuities
member.summary: Inserts leads and links between continuous segments where there is an angular change in tool axis between neighboring segments. This ensures that any reorientation of the tool axis at a specific point takes place away from the part.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.AngularThreshold
member.summary: Enter the minimum angle required before leads and links are inserted. The angle is the change in the tool axis between neighbouring segments.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.GougeCheck
member.summary: Select this option for Powermill to gouge-check all leads and links.

members.member:
The distance at which a short link becomes a long link.
threshold

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.RetractAndApproachMoves
member.summary: The length and orientation of the link moves.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.AutomaticallyExtend
member.summary: Select to lengthen the retract and approach moves made within rapid links. This enables the moves to reach the surface, over which the rapid or skim moves are made. This also lengthens the initial move at the start, and the final move at the end.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.MaxMoveExtension
member.summary: The maximum length of the extension.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.RetractDistance
member.summary: The length of the Retract move.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.ApproachDistance
member.summary: The length of the Approach move.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.ArcFitRapidMove
member.summary:
Use these options to place arcs on the corners of link moves as the tool rapids across the part. This avoids sudden changes in direction and is useful when high speed machining.
When the option is deselected, rapid moves are linear and form right-angles with the link moves When the option is selected, rapid moves are curved and form arcs with the link moves. The arc radius is controlled by the TDU

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMConnections.ArcFitRadius
member.summary: The TDU radius to control the .

member.name: T:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.ExtensionLeadMoveTypes
member.summary: a 's move type to be used before each cutting move

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.ExtensionLeadMoveTypes.None
member.summary: There are no leads in or out applied to the toolpath. This is the default option.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.ExtensionLeadMoveTypes.Straight
member.summary: This inserts a straight move at the end of each cutting move. The direction of the move is determined by the Angle.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.ExtensionLeadMoveTypes.SurfaceNormalArc
member.summary: This inserts a tangential arc move at the end of each cutting path. This arc lies in the plane defined by the toolpath's tangent direction and the surface normal.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.ExtensionLeadMoveTypes.VerticalArc
member.summary: This inserts a tangential arc move at the end of each cutting path. This arc lies in a plane containing the tangent direction and the tool axis.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.ExtensionLeadMoveTypes.HorizontalArc
member.summary: This inserts a tangential arc move at the end of each cutting path. This arc lies in the plane containing the tool axis and the tangent direction, rotated by 90DegreesSymbol about the tangent direction.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.ExtensionLeadMoveTypes.ExtendedMove
member.summary: This inserts a straight tangential move at the end of each cutting move.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.ExtensionLeadMoveTypes.Boxed
member.summary: This inserts a horizontal move at the end of each cutting move.

member.name: T:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.RampFollow
member.summary: Direction of .

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.RampFollow.ToolPath
member.summary: The ramp moves follow the profile of the toolpath.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.RampFollow.Line
member.summary: The ramp moves are normal to the cutting direction at that point. If the requested line cannot be fitted into the area, then the Toolpath option is used automatically.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.RampFollow.Circle
member.summary: The ramp moves are circular. If the requested circle cannot be fitted into the area, then the Line method is used automatically.

member.name: T:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.RampHeight
member.summary: Select how to determine the height from which the ramp descends

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.RampHeight.IncrementalRamp
member.summary: The height above the cleared stock for the start of the ramp.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.RampHeight.Segment
member.summary: The start of the ramp is at the same height as the end of the previous toolpath segment, provided that this is higher than the toolpath segment by the amount specified in the Height field.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.RampHeight.SegmentIncremental
member.summary: The start of the ramp is at the same height as the end of the previous toolpath segment plus the height specified in the Height field.

member.name: T:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.LinkTypes
member.summary: The type of link moves to connect consecutive cutting passes for links shorter than the Short/Long threshold value.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.LinkTypes.Safe
member.summary: The tool moves to the safe area before making the link move.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.LinkTypes.Incremental
member.summary: The tool descends at rapid feed from the safe area to the specified incremental distance above the target point, and then plunges the remaining distance. If you have a multi-axis toolpath, the tool retracts a set distance along the tool axis and then retracts to the safe area. It comes down from the safe area and completes the approach along the tool axis. The distance moved along the tool axis is controlled by the Plunge Distance on the Z Heights

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.LinkTypes.Skim
member.summary: The links traverse clear of the part by the specified incremental distance, descend at rapid feed to the specified incremental distance above the contact point, and then plunge the remaining distance

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.LinkTypes.OnSurface
member.summary: The links follow the surface of the triangulated model, and so prevent gouging.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.LinkTypes.Stepdown
member.summary: The links traverse clear of the part by an amount, so that with the specified the vertical descent will reach the next contact point

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.LinkTypes.Straight
member.summary: Straight-line moves are used. These straight moves between raster paths could cause gouging over curved areas of the model.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.LinkTypes.CircularArc
member.summary: The tool moves are circular.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.CoolantOptions.Standard

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.CoolantOptions.Mist

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.CoolantOptions.Tap

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.CoolantOptions.Air
member.summary: Turns the coolant to air blast.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.CoolantOptions.Through
member.summary: Turns the coolant to through spindle.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.CoolantOptions.Double
member.summary: Enables two coolant codes.

member.summary: The length to extend the Lead move before the cutting move starts. If this is an arc move, then the distance is the length of the linear tangential move between the arc and the cutting portion of the toolpath.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMLead.Angle
member.summary: The angle of the Lead move relative to the toolpath segment. For arcs, this is the angle spanned by the arc. For lines, it is the orientation relative to the cutting move.

member.summary: The radius of the Lead arc move

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMLead.Ramp
member.summary: enables you to specify how the tool ramps into the stock.

member.name: T:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveType
member.summary: a 's move type to be used before each cutting move

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveType.None
member.summary: There are no leads in or out applied to the toolpath. This is the default option.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveType.Straight
member.summary: This inserts a straight move at the end of each cutting move. The direction of the move is determined by the Angle.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveType.SurfaceNormalArc
member.summary: This inserts a tangential arc move at the end of each cutting path. This arc lies in the plane defined by the toolpath's tangent direction and the surface normal.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveType.VerticalArc
member.summary: This inserts a tangential arc move at the end of each cutting path. This arc lies in a plane containing the tangent direction and the tool axis.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveType.HorizontalArc
member.summary: This inserts a tangential arc move at the end of each cutting path. This arc lies in the plane containing the tool axis and the tangent direction, rotated by 90DegreesSymbol about the tangent direction.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveType.ExtendedMove
member.summary: This inserts a straight tangential move at the end of each cutting move.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveType.Boxed
member.summary: This inserts a horizontal move at the end of each cutting move.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveType.Ramp
member.summary: This ramps the tool into the model at a specified angle. This enables you to use a non-plunging tool, but is dependent on the tool and the material. Selecting this option enables the Ramp options button.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.MoveType.PocketCentre
member.summary: Pocket centre — This produces a tangential lead move that, in the case of a Lead In, starts at the centre of the pocket ( a Lead Out finishes at the centre). The centre is the centre of the box that encloses the closed segment. This option is particularly useful when profiling pocket features which have been pre-drilled at the centre, although it can be used with any closed segment.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMRamp.MaxZigAngle
member.summary: The angle of descent formed as the tool ramps into the block.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMRamp.Follow
member.summary: Select how to control the direction of the .

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMRamp.CircleDiameter
member.summary: The diameter of the circle using tool diameter units (TDUs). Tool diameter units is the distance relative to the tool diameter. So, a 10 mm tool and a TDU of 2, gives an actual value of 20 mm.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMRamp.ClosedSegments
member.summary: When selected, the ramp moves are inserted only into closed segments.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMRamp.RampHeight
member.summary: This is measured with respect to the tool axis. For 3-axis machining, the tool axis is the Z axis. For multi-axis machining, Ramp hight height the tool axis is specified on the Tool Axis dialog.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMRamp.RampHeightValue
member.summary: the height of the start of the ramp above the option selected in the Type field

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMRamp.FiniteRamp
member.summary: When selected, enter a maximum ramp length.When deselected, the tool ramps down in a single pass

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMRamp.FiniteRampLenght
member.summary: Enter the maximum ramp length. This determines the number of zig and zag moves required in the ramp. This value is represented in TDUs. Tool diameter units is the distance relative to the tool diameter. So, a 10 mm tool and a TDU of 2, gives an actual value of 20 mm.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMRamp.ZagAngle
member.summary: When selected, you can enter a different Zag Angle from the Zig Angle. When deselected, the Zag Angle is the same as the Zig Angle. The second angle of descent is used if the tool doesn't reach the start of the toolpath segment in a single pass.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMRamp.ZagAngleMaximum
member.summary: Enter the angle of descent formed as the tool ramps into the block. This is specified in the same way as the Zig Angle.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMRamp.Extend
member.summary: Select to extend the ramp moves at the start or end of a toolpath. If you select a of , this option extends a Ramp Lead In (or Lead Out) to the end (or start) of its associated toolpath segment.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMToolpath.SurfaceSpeed
member.summary: Speed of the tool during material removal, represents the rate at which the cutting edges of the tool can be driven through the material. Any changes made to value recalculates , Rate, and Rate.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMToolpath.CuttingFeed
member.summary: Cutting feed rate. Any changes made to value updates

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMToolpath.FeedPerTooth
member.summary: Cutting feed per tooth, is determined by the construction of the tool, and may be limited by the strength of the cutting edges or the capacity of the tool to remove swarf. Any changes made to value recalculates Rate and Rate

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMToolpath.LeadInFactor
member.summary: Controls the speed of the tool as it approaches the stock, before beginning a cutting move.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMToolpath.LeadOutFactor
member.summary: Controls the speed of the tool after it leaves the stock, at the end of a cutting move.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMToolpath.PlungingFeed
member.summary: Speed of the tool when entering the material ready for its cutting moves. When 3-axis machining, these are vertical moves.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMToolpath.SkimFeed
member.summary: Feed rate for straight line moves from point A to point B. If everything is totally safe, the machine moves at rapid which usually appears as G0 in the output file. For skim moves, the machine performs a linear move (which G0 moves do not guarantee), normally G1 in the output file, at a very high feed rate.

member.name: P:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.PMToolpath.SpindleSpeed
member.summary: Rotation of the spindle, measured in revolutions per minute. If you edit this value then value automatically updates to reflect your change.

member.name: T:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.StartPointMethod
member.summary: Defines how the start point is set.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.StartPointMethod.Absolute
member.summary: The start point is positioned independently of all other properties at the point defined by the Coordinates field.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.StartPointMethod.BlockCentre
member.summary: The start point is at Safe Z above the block centre:

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.StartPointMethod.FirstPoint
member.summary: The start point is positioned at the specified distance from the first point in the toolpath, measured along its tool axis.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.StartPointMethod.FirstPointSafe
member.summary: The start point is at Safe Z above the first point in the toolpath. For multi-axis toolpaths, the start point is set by considering a point that is the specified distance from the first point on the toolpath, measured along the tool axis, and projecting this onto the Safe Z area.

member.name: T:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.ToolpathSafety
member.summary: Indicates the safety of various parts of the toolpath.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.ToolpathSafety.NotChecked
member.summary: Safty unchecked

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.ToolpathSafety.Safe
member.summary: Tool does not gouge .

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.ToolpathSafety.Collides
member.summary: Tool gouges

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.BreakChip
member.summary: Drills the holes in several stages (multiple peck) only retracting a small amount after each peck.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.CounterBore
member.summary: The second of the boring cycles (G86).

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.DeepDrill
member.summary: Drills the holes in several stages (multiple peck).

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.ExternalThread
member.summary: Creates an external thread on a boss.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.FineBoring
member.summary: An alternative deep drilling cycle, so may be used for machines with a variety of deep drilling cycles.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.Helical
member.summary: Bores out a large hole with a small tool. The concept is similar to trochoidal milling. The difference between the two is that trochoidal milling machines a slot (no variation in Z) and helical milling drills a hole (machines down the Z axis).

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.Profile
member.summary: Drills the hole using circular moves. A tool smaller than the size of the hole is required. At each depth, the tool moves on to the edge of the hole using a circular arc lead with a straight extension, cuts a circle, and then moves back to the centre with a circular arc lead and straight extension. You may use a thickness value to create a smaller hole.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.Ream
member.summary: The first of the boring cycles (G85).

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.RigidTapping
member.summary: Enables you to enter a Peck depth as well as a Pitch.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.SinglePeck
member.summary: Drills the holes in one operation.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.Tap
member.summary: Drills the holes in one direction and reverses out.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.ThreadMill
member.summary: A cycle similar to reverse helical but with improved leads in and out for thread creation.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.Bore
member.summary: These correspond to the third, fourth, and fifth type of boring cycle (G87-G89) normally found on a machine tool. The difference between the boring operations varies from machine tool to machine tool.

member.name: F:Autodesk.ProductInterface.PowerMILL.DrillCycleTypes.ReverseHelical
member.summary: A second helical drill cycle. This bores out a large hole with a small tool. It performs a helical movement from the bottom of the hole. Use this for finishing a hole as you can use it only with a pre-drilled hole.
